results.title: The Middle Ages
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
History of the Middle Ages from Charlemagne examined through art, monasteries, agriculture and invasions. Illustrated by 15th century miniatures, the film gives a good background to European history, literature and art.

results.title: Towards a modern Europe: the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Explains and illustrates the transition from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance, including the principles of the new study and attitudes in art, architecture and scholarship

results.title: The Romans
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Presents the origins, growth and collapse of the Roman Empire. Describes how the Romans imitated the greek ideal of the city state and how they expanded over a period of 400 years, emerging as the ruling force of the world. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: An Age of Revolutions. Great Britain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Revolution, nationalism, liberty, war, and industrialisation, were the main themes in the history of Europe from 1789 to 1870. This looks at the effects of the two main revolutions in this time, on the whole of Europe. The French Revolution brought new ideas and politics, and the Industrial Revolution brought new wealth and motives, and an urban industrialised society

results.title: An Introduction to Psychology
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Perceptual learning (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “An Introduction to Psychology”.
Traces the different approaches adopted in research into the way in which a child learns to coordinate his actions in relation to the world around him. Looks at a number of famous experiments including the Visual Cliff, Inverted Prism and dark-reared animals. Also demonstrates some of the perceptual processes on which they are based.

results.title: American Enterprise

group_works.title: Introduction film for the American Enterprise series
group_works.creator_credit: James C. Crimmins, Mike Jackson and Playback Associates

results.title: People
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Tom Novak, community college professor of Ethnic Studies, visits Ellis Island, where he reminisces about the early immigrants (16 million between 1890 and 1930) who helped shape America. Novak introduces us to some of their descendants in their homes and businesses. Japanese florists in California, Portuguese fishermen in Massachusetts and an Afro-American family in Long Island are featured. Narrated by William Shatner.

group_siblings.title: Organization

results.title: Organization
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Lew Kraft, a successful and dynamic businessman, who is building a large shopping centre, opens up the intriguing and complex world of high finance and organisational know-how. The film then traces American economics from 18th century examples of community and farm organisation, through the complexity of the industrial and transportation revolutions, to modern-day international investments and multinational corporations and the organisational knack of Americans. With William Shatner.
